speech.para: The other matter raised by the honorable member for Fawkner is one in which I am also interested. I have fought for the rights of these men for two years, but I have been unable to get any satisfaction from the authorities. The men are mainly flying instructors. The deferred pay that was due to them was withheld under a retrospective regulation. As the honorable member for Fawkner said, other men in the same category who were discharged, received the full amount, and the money was credited to the estates of those who died. I have been unable to get any satisfaction from the Department of Air. Unfortunately, the man whose case I pleaded in this House took his life. The men concerned in this matter include approximately 25 flying instructors and other personnel such as medical officers, legal officers, &c. One of the men took his case to the

Supreme Court of New .South Wales, and won, but the Commonwealth appealed to the High Court and had the verdict upset. However, justices of the High Court were most scathing in their condemnation of the Government's action. Before going overseas, the Attorney-General (Dr. Evatt) assured me that an ex gratia payment would be made in respect of the flying instructors. I understand that no such payment has yet been made. Consideration of the position of the other personnel has been deferred.

talk.start.para: - Payment should not be restricted to the flying instructors.

- That is so. They all should be paid. If employees in any industry were deprived of money to which they were entitled, honorable members opposite would be severely critical. This state of affairs should not be tolerated. Many of the men concerned were invited to join the Royal Australian Air Force. I hope that the matter will be settled without delay.

. - In accordance with the wishes of the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Holt), and the honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. White), I shall discuss this matter with the Prime Minister (Mr. Chifley) in his capacity as Treasurer to-morrow morning, and ascertain whether or not a decision has been reached. speech.para: The Bunnerong dispute has upset me just as much as it has upset the honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Harrison). talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that ex-prisoners-of-war officers were paid an allowance on return to Australia to compensate them for their personal equipment lost and also for their field allowance?
If so, will he state the amounts paidin accordance with rank?
Is it a fact that an amount of 2 10s. is allowed to other ranks as compensation if they apply for it?
If so, will he issue instructions that adequate payment in compensation be made to other ranks?

Is it a fact that senior medical officers who were prisoners of war in Malaya made promotions of other ranks because of their untiring and faithful duty in volunteering to nurse the cholera cases on the Burma railway?
Were any of those temporary promotions recognized; if not, why not?
Will he give an assurance that the payment of the 3s. per day allowance to other ranks who were prisoners of war will be given further consideration when reparations are being considered?
Is it a fact thatsome prisoner-of-war officers in Malaya arrived back in Australia with a much higher rank than their rank at the day of rescue?
If so, why was discrimination shown and promotions recommended refused to other ranks who volunteered to nurse the sick during the indescribable horror of the cholera camps on the Burma railway?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: Ex-prisoner-of-war male officers were paid an amount not exceeding their original outfit allowance of 25 in compensation for certain specified items of personal equipment lost or destroyed on service, subject to their furnishing satisfactory evidence that the articles for which compensation was claimed had been lost and also subject to their supplying evidence that they purchased again from their own resources the articles in respect of which the claims were made. Field allowance is a normal pay allowance credited to officers, male and female, while they are rationed and quartered by the Army, and are in receipt of ordinary pay. It was. also paid to all officers continuously while they were prisoners of war.

Compensation to male officers for equipment lost did not exceed 25 in any one case. Field allowance was paid to all male officers, irrespective of rank while serving overseas, at the rate of 3s. 4d. per day, Australian currency.
Male other ranks may be paid an amount not exceeding 2 2s. 5d. for pertain specified items of clothing under the same conditions as are set out in (1).
It is not proposed to make any payments additional to those which have been authorized.
In several instances Australian Army Medical Corps officers commanding working parties made promotions to local acting unpaid rank.

Promotions were to local acting unpaid rank only, and were effected for command and control purposes and to gain the benefit of increased Japanese pay for non-commissioned officers- Subsequent to the release of the prisoners of war in Japanese hands the question of the recognition of these acting ranks was considered fully and it was decided that the established policy that no promotions of officers and other ranks were to be made whilst they were prisoners of war would continue tu apply.
This matter is at present under consideration by the Government.
There is no known case of an officer arriving back in Australia with rank higher thou his rank on the day of rescue.
See answer to No. 8.

talk.start.para: On the 14th November, the honorable member for Bendigo (Mr. Rankin) asked a question concerning the position in regard to taxation of amounts expended by primary producers on the erection of silos. The position is as follows : -

quote.para: Section 54 of the act provides for the allowance to primary producers of deductions by way of depreciation on structural improvements, other than structural improvements used for domestic or residential purposes, on land which ia used for agricultural or pastoral pursuits. This provision would include silos erected for the purpose of storing wheat in the course of carrying on a business of wheatfarming.

The rate of depreciation allowable varies according to the estimated effective life of the unit, assuming that it is maintained in reasonably good order and condition. In the case of grain Hos constructed of galvanized iron, the rate of depreciation -which has been fixed is 3 per ent. per annum.

In addition to the deduction for normal depreciation, a special initial depreciation allowance is granted in respect of plant and other depreciable assets acquired by taxpayers during the period of five years ending on the 30th June, 11)50. This special allowance is deductible in the year in which the particular asset is acquired, constructed or installed. The deduction is an amount equal to 20 per cent, of the cost of the asset, and is allowable in addition to the normal depreciation, ' the latter being calculated on the balance of the cost after deducting the initial allowance of 20 per cent.

The act further provides that any loss ou disposal of depreciable assets, whether by sale, demolition or otherwise, shall be an allowable deduction. This deduction is allowable in year of disposal. lt will thus bc Been that primary producers who incur expenditure in the construction of silos during the current financial year will be entitled to the following deductions: - (a) a special initial depreciation allowance equal to 20 -per cent, of the cost of construction of the silo; \b) normal depreciation at the appropriate rate; and (c) any loss sustained in consequence of the disposal or demolition of the structure.
